descriptionSet.description: On this poster, a family can be seen enjoying together at their well furnished house. The Mother is sitting on a couch, reading a magazine, while father is sitting next to her, slightly elevated, smoking a cigarette. Close to the couch, a boy and a girl can be seen, sitting on the ground and chatting with each other.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: On this poster, a family can be seen enjoying together at their well furnished house. The Mother is sitting on a couch, reading a magazine, while father is sitting next to her, slightly elevated, smoking a cigarette. Close to the couch, a boy and a girl can be seen, sitting on the ground and chatting with each other. (gs)
text-en: 324

explanatory comments/crosstagging: When family members do appear in the modern home, women appear in the warm glow of compassionate marriage. When gathered in the drawing room they enjoy the private pleasure of reading under the husband’s approving gaze. Children might appear in both these images, but only as passive spectators or miniaturized accessories to marital bliss, not active participants in the family in their own right. (Abigail McGowan) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This promised, romanticized autonomy of the modern female consumer has distinct limits. For one, it presumes the male gaze. For every image of a woman pursuing her own desires through tea, reading, or conversation, others offer visions of women poised to satisfy the desires of men. Men are not depicted, leaving the women to still appear alone. (Abigail McGowan) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This could well be a scene from a film. Interestingly, the spatial composition reminds of miniature painting. The scene is surreal in that the children are miniaturised adults, look like dolls, and the full moon has risen over a silhouette of houses or trees and lightens the large veranda of the house. The blue sofa is like a chaise longue. The couple shares something, their knowledge of the letter that the woman is about to read - he looks as if he already knows what it says, and she is reading it silently. both are very serious and there is a certain dose of drama in the scene. One keeps wondering why she had covered her head though she is in the house - is he a stranger, and not her husband? (cb)
